prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA – for wanting to use ‘lads’ and ‘guys’ to a mixed group
  

I play an online team game which is 99% male players. Recently we asked a girl to join our team, lets call her Jane. After match we often say stuff like ‘well done boiz’ and she told us that makes her feel like not part of the team and suggested we say something like ‘well done team’ instead. We all agreed to try, she is part of the team and as good as any of us guys. Jane has said it is difficult for a girl to play in an all male group but I don’t see why as we treat her well.

Yesterday one guy posted in group chat that he could not attend a practice and said ‘Have fun lads and Jane’. Jane responded by telling him that was worse than just saying ‘lads’ and made her feel ‘othered’.

The group had a bit of a chat about it and I said I was gonna keep using ‘lads’ and ‘guys’ because I mean the whole team when I say that and I am not giving in to radical feminism. 

The guy who started this though, said he was sorry for what he wrote and he was trying to include her and he would try to refer to team or people in future.

I ought to be able to use normal words without overly sensitive people feeling hurt by it. I am surprised that some of the other guys are taking her side though.
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The author is part of an online gaming team that's mostly male, and they invited a girl named Jane. The team used terms like "boiz" and "lads," which Jane found exclusionary. She suggested using "team" instead. The author then defends using "lads" and "guys," even when someone accidentally included Jane in the greeting, which she found even worse. The author claims they're not giving in to radical feminism and that others are overreacting.

Hmm, the key points here are about inclusivity and how language affects people's feelings. Even if the author's intention was to include the whole team, the words they use might unintentionally exclude Jane. The fact that Jane has mentioned it's hard to be in an all-male group suggests she already feels some level of discomfort. When the guy said "lads and Jane," that might have highlighted her as different, making her feel othered. The author's response of sticking with "lads" and dismissing it as radical feminism could be seen as not considering Jane's perspective.

So, is the author in the wrong? Well, they are aware Jane feels excluded, and they're continuing to use terms she finds problematic. Even if the intention is good, the impact matters. By not making an effort to use inclusive language, they might be contributing to Jane's feeling of not belonging. The author's dismissal of her feelings as being "overly sensitive" or "radical" isn't helpful. The correct approach would be to respect her feelings and adjust language to include everyone. Therefore, the author is in the wrong.
